paper_abstract: The superposition calculus (Bachmair and Ganzinger, J. Log Comput. 3(4), 217-247, 1994; Nieuwenhuis and Rubio 1994) is the state-of-the-art inference system used in saturation-based theorem proving for first-order logic with equality.We present an extension of this calculus that permits us to reason on formulae built on primal grammars (Hermann and GalbavA1/2, Theor. Comput. Sci. 176(1-2), 111-158, 1997) a schematization language that has been devised to denote infinite sequences of structurally similar terms, defined by primitive recursion. We prove that the calculus is sound and refutationally complete.
paper_title: A Complete Superposition Calculus for Primal Grammars
